intro: Cephalonoplos segetum, commonly known as the field crownflower, is a flowering plant native to the temperate regions of the northern hemisphere. It belongs to the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads and ray florets. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, with lance-shaped leaves and yellow-orange flowers that bloom in the summer. It thrives in well-drained soils and is often found in meadows and along roadsides. Its botanical features make it an important species for pollinators and a potential candidate for ecological restoration projects.
